articles.headline: Judges Find Wisconsin Redistricting Unfairly Favored Republicans
articles.snippet: A federal panel called the 2011 redrawing of Wisconsin Assembly districts an unconstitutional gerrymander, ruling in a case that could go to the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: A federal panel called the 2011 redrawing of Wisconsin Assembly districts an unconstitutional gerrymander, ruling in a case that could go to the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges said on Monday that the Wisconsin Legislature’s 2011 redrawing of State Assembly districts to favor Republicans was an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander, the first such ruling in three decades of pitched legal battles over the issue.

articles.headline: Law Firms, Struggling Financially, Cull Partner Ranks
articles.snippet: The latest to publicly weigh such a step is Shearman & Sterling, which indicated that it would reshape its structure, primarily through demotions.
articles.abstract: The latest to publicly weigh such a step is Shearman & Sterling, which indicated that it would reshape its structure, primarily through demotions.
articles.lead_paragraph: To make partner at a big law firm is to grab a brass ring of prestige, wealth and security.

articles.headline: Trump, on YouTube, Pledges to Create Jobs
articles.snippet: Reading from a script in an update on the transition, the president-elect struck a softer tone, avoiding topics like terrorism and immigration.
articles.abstract: Reading from a script in an update on the transition, the president-elect struck a softer tone, avoiding topics like terrorism and immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday released a two-and-a-half-minute infomercial-style video, turning to social media to deliver a direct-to-camera message in which he vowed to create jobs, renegotiate trade agreements, end restrictions on energy production and impose bans on lobbying.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Small Banks Cheer Trump. So, After a Pause, Do Big Ones.
articles.snippet: Community bankers overwhelmingly supported Donald J. Trump’s campaign. Now, as mega-banks’ stock soars, they too are looking ahead to the benefits of his administration.
articles.abstract: Community bankers overwhelmingly supported Donald J. Trump’s campaign. Now, as mega-banks’ stock soars, they too are looking ahead to the benefits of his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington lobbyists, financial and policy analysts and Wall Street insiders are all trying to figure out what the Trump administration will mean for the banking industry.

articles.headline: Fake News Onslaught Targets Pizzeria as Nest of Child-Trafficking
articles.snippet: A Washington restaurant is reeling from menacing calls and online abuse after a fake story: that Hillary Clinton abuses children there.
articles.abstract: A Washington restaurant is reeling from menacing calls and online abuse after a fake story: that Hillary Clinton abuses children there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days before the presidential election, James Alefantis, owner of a local pizza restaurant called Comet Ping Pong, noticed an unusual spike in the number of his Instagram followers.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Business Dealings Test a Constitutional Limit
articles.snippet: If Mr. Trump continues, once inaugurated, to profit from transactions with companies controlled by foreign governments, he may run afoul of the Emoluments Clause.
articles.abstract: If Mr. Trump continues, once inaugurated, to profit from transactions with companies controlled by foreign governments, he may run afoul of the Emoluments Clause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after he took office, President Obama sought advice from the Justice Department about a potential conflict of interest involving a foreign government. He wanted to know whether he could accept the Nobel Peace Prize.

articles.headline: Investors Make Bullish Bet on Trump, and an Era of Tax Cuts and Spending
articles.snippet: The current wave of enthusiasm recalls the early days of Ronald Reagan after his election in 1980.
articles.abstract: The current wave of enthusiasm recalls the early days of Ronald Reagan after his election in 1980.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Donald J. Trump swept to victory, investors from around the world are betting that his promises of tax cuts, fewer regulations and a spendthrift federal government can recharge the American economy.

articles.headline: Trump’s Focus on Generals for Top Jobs Stirs Worries Over Military’s Sway
articles.snippet: Turning to retired officers worries national security experts and even other retired generals, who say that it could lead to an undue emphasis on military force in foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Turning to retired officers worries national security experts and even other retired generals, who say that it could lead to an undue emphasis on military force in foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump ran for president boasting that he knew more about fighting terrorists than America’s generals.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A Trade War Against China Might Be a Fight Trump Couldn’t Win
articles.snippet: While China would suffer under a 45 percent tariff, it might be able to take the blow and it would certainly counterpunch.
articles.abstract: While China would suffer under a 45 percent tariff, it might be able to take the blow and it would certainly counterpunch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who gains from a trade war with China?

articles.headline: Donald Trump Drops Threat of New Hillary Clinton Investigation
articles.snippet: “Lock her up”? The president-elect signaled that he would prefer to move on rather than pursue inquiries into Mrs. Clinton’s email use and the Clinton Foundation.
articles.abstract: “Lock her up”? The president-elect signaled that he would prefer to move on rather than pursue inquiries into Mrs. Clinton’s email use and the Clinton Foundation.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he had no intention of pressing for an investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server or the financial operations of her family’s foundation, dropping the “lock her up” pledge that became a rallying cry for his campaign for the White House.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: What Will Trump Trade Policy Actually Look Like? Three Possibilities
articles.snippet: It’s possible that there will be only minimal disruptions to world economies, and better deals for American companies. Or not.
articles.abstract: It’s possible that there will be only minimal disruptions to world economies, and better deals for American companies. Or not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, through decades in public life, has been consistent on one core policy idea: that the United States has gotten a raw deal from its major trading partners in the agreements that bind their economies. Renegotiating those terms will surely be a top priority for his administration.
